sentences: Steven Gene Wold (né Leach, 19 March 1951), commonly known as Seasick Steve, is an American blues musician.
section: N/A

sentences: He plays mostly personalized guitars and sings, usually about his early life doing casual work.
section: N/A

sentences: From the late 1960s, he worked as a musician and recording engineer in the US and Europe; he played bass in Shanti, was in a disco band called Crystal Grass as well as other bands.
section: N/A

sentences: He also pursued other works, including producing an album for  Modest Mouse.
section: N/A

sentences: He achieved his breakthrough, initially in the UK, at the end of 2006 when he appeared on Jools Holland's annual Hootenanny as Seasick Steve.
section: N/A

sentences: He has since released a number of commercially successful albums, including I Started Out with Nothin and I Still Got Most of It Left, Man from Another Time, and Sonic Soul Surfer.
section: N/A
== Life and career ==

sentences: Life and career ==
section: == Life and career ==

sentences: The publicity about Wold at the time he first became successful in Britain, in the mid-2000s, suggested that he was then aged in his sixties, and emphasised his past as a hobo in Tennessee and Mississippi.
section: == Life and career ==

sentences: In a 2008 interview in Memphis, Wold was quoted as stating: "I came down here as a young feller looking for the blues, but I didn't find them...   Wasn't in Clarksdale but an hour before a big, old redneck policeman ran me right out of town again.
section: == Life and career ==

sentences: That was how it was back then, and there were some places hereabouts you just didn't go if you were a hobo."
section: == Life and career ==

sentences: By his own account, he would travel long distances by hopping freight trains, looking for work as a farm laborer or in other seasonal jobs.
section: == Life and career ==

sentences: He claimed that he had worked at a carnival, as a cowboy and as a migrant worker.
section: == Life and career ==

sentences: In a 2007 interview, he said: "I rode them [freight trains] for 14 years off and on..", adding "I've been married to this one girl for 25 years, so I’m a little bit settled down now..."In 2016, an unauthorized biography by Matthew Wright presented evidence that parts of Wold's backstory may have been exaggerated.
section: == Life and career ==

sentences: Wright drew on interviews with Wold's estranged eldest son as well as previously published material covering his career in music since the late 1960s, and commented that Wold was "retiring about facts of his own life".
section: == Life and career ==
== Life and career == | === Childhood and early life ===

sentences: Childhood and early life =
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and early life ===
== Life and career == | === Childhood and early life ===

sentences: Steve Wold was born in Oakland, California, as Steven Gene Leach, though his biographer suggests that he may have been adopted as a baby.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and early life ===

sentences: He took the surname Wold in the early 1980s, from that of his second wife.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and early life ===

sentences: Official birth records confirm his birth year as 1951.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and early life ===

sentences: In 2000, he gave his age as 50, though later publicity implied that he was older and some sources such as Allmusic claim he was born in 1941.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and early life ===

sentences: When he was four years old, his parents split up and he continued to live with his mother.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and early life ===

sentences: He claimed that as a child he was taught to play the guitar by K. C. Douglas, who worked at his grandfather's garage, and later realised that he had been taught the blues.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and early life ===

sentences: Douglas wrote the song "Mercury Blues" and had played with Tommy Johnson in the early 1940s.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and early life ===

sentences: His mother remarried, to a Korean War veteran who Wold characterized as abusive, and, at the age of about 13, Wold claimed that he left home following a violent confrontation with his stepfather.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and early life ===

sentences: Wold claimed to have lived rough and on the road in Tennessee, Mississippi and elsewhere, until at least the late 1960s.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and early life ===

sentences: However, Wright's biography claims that Wold lived in Haight-Ashbury, San Francisco, for some time from 1965.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and early life ===

sentences: He attended the Monterey Pop Festival, regularly saw bands such as The Grateful Dead perform in the area, and became acquainted with Janis Joplin and Jimi Hendrix.
section: == Life and career == | === Childhood and early life ===
== Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: Early musical activities ===
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: In about 1969, he toured clubs in the region as a backing musician with Lightnin' Hopkins.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: In 1970, as Steve Leach, he became the bass player in an innovative band, Shanti, who performed a fusion of Indian and rock music.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: Other band members included Zakir Hussain and Aashish Khan, and all the band members were adherents of Transcendental Meditation.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: In liner notes for a 2015 reissue of Shanti's only album, writer Richie Unterberger states that "bassist Steve Leach has reinvented himself as the blues musician Seasick Steve", and his participation in Shanti was confirmed by Seattle band the Tremens.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: He left California in 1972 and moved to Paris, France, where he busked in the Métro.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: He occasionally returned to California where he married Victoria Johnson in 1974; they had two sons together but later divorced.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: Wold also spent time in the 1970s in Hawaii, and worked as a session musician and studio engineer, as well as in occasional manual jobs.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: He has claimed to have played with other musicians including Son House, John Lee Hooker, Albert King, and Joni Mitchell around this time.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: In 1976, he worked with French producer Lee Hallyday and fronted the disco group Crystal Grass.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: Leach appeared on two Crystal Grass albums released by Philips Records in France, Dance Up a Storm and Ocean Potion, the latter credited to Steve Leach with the Crystal Grass Orchestra.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: The group also released several singles including "You Can Be What You Dream".
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: He also sang on the first album released by Mike Love's side project Celebration, a collaboration with members of the Paris-based band King Harvest.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: Around 1980, Steve Leach returned to Europe.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: In 1982, he appeared as singer and guitarist on an album, Women and Sports, by the band Clean, Athletic & Talented (C.A.T.), co-writing their single "I Love To Touch Young Girls".
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: He met Elisabeth Wold in a blues bar in Oslo, Norway, and adopted her surname after she became his second wife.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: For a time in the early 1980s, he lived in London, and then with Elisabeth in Skelmersdale, England, which biographer Wright notes is the location of a major Transcendental Meditation movement center.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: He later claimed to have run a recording studio in Europe before selling it.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: After returning to the US, he trained as a paramedic, before moving with his wife and their three sons from Nashville, Tennessee, to Olympia, near Seattle, in 1991.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: The move was partly motivated by Elisabeth Wold's desire to live in an area reminiscent of her native Norway, but also reflected the area's developing indie music scene.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: In Olympia, Wold established his own guitar store and recording studio, Moon Music.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: He was acquainted with Kurt Cobain, and began producing records by local musicians, including Kathleen Hanna and Fitz of Depression.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: Wold produced  the 1996 debut album by Modest Mouse, This Is a Long Drive for Someone with Nothing to Think About, and recordings by the band P.E.Z. on which he played guitar.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: He also worked closely with a local band, the Tremens, and with them started to form a band, Dr Steel and the Forty-nines, with himself as singer and lead guitarist, but this fell through.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: A 2001 interview with the Tremens described Wold as a "Pacific Northwest music icon... who has put his recording stamp on some of the most influential bands to come out of Puget Sound.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: "In 2001, Wold closed Moon Music, after being involved in up to 50 albums made there.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: He said at the time: "I'm finished with America.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: I'm 50 years old now, and I've been watching greed play the main stage since I was a teenager.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: I just can't stand it anymore."
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: With his wife and their sons, he moved to Notodden in Norway, home of the Notodden Blues Festival, and set up a studio, Juke Joint, with vintage equipment that he had acquired over the years.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: After Wold became ill on a boat trip between Norway and Denmark, he adopted the name "Seasick Steve" as a parallel to that of blues musician Homesick James, and started to form a band, Seasick Steve and the Level Devils.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: Wold released his first album, entitled Cheap, recorded with the Level Devils as his rhythm section, with Jo Husmo on stand-up bass and Kai Christoffersen on drums.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: His debut solo album, Dog House Music was released by Bronzerat Records on 26 November 2006, after he was championed by an old friend, Joe Cushley, DJ on the Balling The Jack blues show on London radio station Resonance FM.
section: == Life and career == | === Early musical activities ===

sentences: Breakthrough and subsequent career

== Life and career == | === Breakthrough and subsequent career ===

sentences: Wold made his first UK television appearance on Jools Holland's annual Hootenanny BBC TV show on New Year's Eve 2006.
section: == Life and career == | === Breakthrough and subsequent career ===

sentences: He performed a live rendition of "Dog House Boogie" on the "Three String Trance Wonder" and the "Mississippi Drum Machine".
section: == Life and career == | === Breakthrough and subsequent career ===

sentences: After that show his popularity exploded in Britain, and he commented "I can't believe it, all of the sudden I'm like the cat's meow!"He was well received in the UK, winning the 2007 MOJO Award for Best Breakthrough Act and going on to appear at major UK festivals such as Reading, Leeds and Glastonbury.
section: == Life and career == | === Breakthrough and subsequent career ===

sentences: In 2007 he played more UK festivals than any other artist.
section: == Life and career == | === Breakthrough and subsequent career ===

sentences: At that time, it was claimed in press coverage that he was 66 years old, though he was later demonstrated to be ten years younger.
section: == Life and career == | === Breakthrough and subsequent career ===

sentences: Wold toured early in 2008, playing in various venues and festivals in the UK.
section: == Life and career == | === Breakthrough and subsequent career ===

sentences: He was joined on stage by drummer Dan Magnusson.
section: == Life and career == | === Breakthrough and subsequent career ===

sentences: KT Tunstall also dueted with Wold at the London Astoria in January 2008.
section: == Life and career == | === Breakthrough and subsequent career ===

sentences: Wold also played many other festivals throughout the world in 2008, including Fuji Rock in Japan, East Coast Blues & Roots Music Festival in Australia, also in April 2008,  and Roskilde in Denmark.
section: == Life and career == | === Breakthrough and subsequent career ===

sentences: Wold's major-label debut, I Started Out with Nothin and I Still Got Most of It Left was recorded with Dan Magnusson on drums, was released by Warner Music on 29 September 2008, and features Ruby Turner and Nick Cave's Grinderman.
section: == Life and career == | === Breakthrough and subsequent career ===

sentences: He has toured the UK extensively since 2007 being supported by performers including Duke Garwood, Gemma Ray, Billie the Vision and the Dancers, Amy LaVere, Melody Nelson and Joe Gideon & The Shark.
section: == Life and career == | === Breakthrough and subsequent career ===

sentences: His tours in October 2008 and January 2009 were all sold out and included performances at the Royal Albert Hall, the Edinburgh Queen's Hall, the Grand Opera House in Belfast, the Apollo in Manchester, the City Hall in Newcastle and the London Hammersmith Apollo.
section: == Life and career == | === Breakthrough and subsequent career ===

sentences: In 2009, Wold was nominated for a Brit Award in the category of International Solo Male Artist, That same year, BBC Four broadcast a documentary of Wold visiting the southern USA entitled Seasick Steve: Bringing It All Back Home.
section: == Life and career == | === Breakthrough and subsequent career ===

sentences: On 21 January, Wold hosted "Folk America: Hollerers, Stompers and Old Time Ramblers" at the Barbican in London, a show that was also televised and shown with the documentary on BBC Four as part of a series tracing American roots music.
section: == Life and career == | === Breakthrough and subsequent career ===

sentences: In an interview with an Australian magazine, Wold attributed much of his unlikely success to his cheap and weather-beaten guitar, "The Trance Wonder" and reveals the guitar's mojo might come from supernatural sources.
section: == Life and career == | === Breakthrough and subsequent career ===

sentences: I say, 'What are you talking about, Sherman?'.

sentences: You'd put it down somewhere and the next morning you'd come back and it would have moved.

sentences: When you took that guitar the ghost in the barn left'.

sentences: A friend of Steve's had given him a guitar made with hubcaps off a Morris Minor (he owned one at the time), and he played it on air.

== Nickname ==

sentences: Nickname ==
section: == Nickname ==

sentences: When asked about his nickname, Wold has said: "because it's just true: I always get seasick".
section: == Nickname ==

sentences: When he was ill on a ferry from Norway to Copenhagen, later in his life, a friend began playfully using the name and, despite Wold not rising to it for a while, it stuck.
section: == Nickname ==

sentences: When asked about his name on British Sunday morning television show, Something for the Weekend, he replied, "I just get sick on boats".
section: == Nickname ==
== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Wold has five adult sons, and has married twice, marrying his second wife in the early 1980s.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Wold has said that he has problems putting down roots in one place, and he and his wife have lived in 59 houses to date, including Norway and the United Kingdom.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Wold's son Didrik is an illustrator, and has designed his father's album artwork, merchandise, print ads, and websites.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: His youngest son, Paul Martin Wold, played drums on Dog House Music and first made a guest appearance with him on percussion at the Astoria in January 2008.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: He has since performed with Wold frequently, playing washboard, shakers, tambourine, floor tom and occasionally guitar.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: He also works as Steve's guitar tech.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Paul Martin Wold, aka "Wishful Thinking", released his debut album A Waste of Time
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Well Spent on 2 November 2009, and showcased a selection from the album whilst touring the UK with his father.
